txt.en:
'Leaflock has done as we hoped he would, [placeholder]. He has sent Huorns to seek Núrzum. Will they prevail against him? I cannot say, but I know this: my heart is stirred by their march!

'They seem so different from you or I, and from Horn or Nona, so far removed from the daily worries of Men or Elves or dwarves. But still they march for us against the evil of Núrzum, against the evil of Saruman.

'Even now Leaflock and his herd have not retreated so far from Middle-earth as to abandon its people. It is worth remembering.

'It seems our friends have remembered something as well, [placeholder]. I told you it would happen, did I not? I am certain I did.'

'Leaflock has done as we hoped he would, [placeholder]. He has sent Huorns to seek Núrzum. Will they prevail against him? I cannot say, but I know this: my heart is stirred by their march!

'They seem so different from you or I, and from Horn or Nona, so far removed from the daily worries of Men or Elves or hobbits. But still they march for us against the evil of Núrzum, against the evil of Saruman.

'Even now Leaflock and his herd have not retreated so far from Middle-earth as to abandon its people. It is worth remembering.

'It seems our friends have remembered something as well, [placeholder]. I told you it would happen, did I not? I am certain I did.'
Instance: The Bloom
'[placeholder], what do you think makes that sound? Is it Núrzum? Has he found this cave at last? We must see what has happened outside!'
'We should go back inside and bring what people we can out here to see this sight, [placeholder]. Who can say when such a marvel will be seen again?'
You suddenly hear a low rumbling from outside the cave!
Your companions are sitting around the fire in Nona's cave, and you should do the same. Simply <rgb=#FF0000>sit</rgb> by the fire and relax while you can.
Your companions are relaxing around the fire in Nona's cave, having earned a small, and overdue, respite.
Nona has leapt to her feet, and wants to see what you think of the rumbling sound.
'From each corner of the land all would ride.'
You have come outside with your companions to see what has happened.
'Well, I suppose it is.'
A mighty force of Huorns are leaving the Balewood. They can have only one destination: Núrzum!
'A city on a hill she was, strong Byre Tor, fair Byre Tor.'
Your companions are transfixed by the sight. Only Corudan can manage the words to describe it.
'From far across the plains her banners we espied.'
'And she was a comfort in time of pain, time of want.'
'But the winter came, and with it an iron tide.'
'What is that sound?'
'A rumble from without!'
'They march, [placeholder]. They march to fight Núrzum.'
'An enemy?'
<rgb=#FF0000>Sit</rgb> by the fire with your companions
Relax around the fire with your companions
Talk to Nona inside the cave
Join Nona outside the cave
Watch the mighty force leaving Balewood
Talk to Corudan on the slope outside the cave
'And it was our day to comfort, our time to protect.'
You have earned a moment's rest with your friends while you wait to see if Leaflock will come through with the aid Corudan thinks you have earned.
'To that city on the hill, strong Byre Tor, fair Byre Tor.'
'We walked slowly forward, unsure of what awaited us.'
'Horn crept before us, sword at the ready...'
'And suddenly a shrew burst forth from the bush, toppling Horn onto his face!'
'Yes, yes, it is a funny story.'
'Master Gléowine, surely you have something else we can speak about?'
'I do have some words concerning Byre Tor. Would that be too painful for our friends?'
'I would like to hear it!'
'I, too, want to hear of my city!'
'That is your answer, bard.'

'Leaflock has done as we hoped he would, [placeholder]. He has sent Huorns to seek Núrzum. Will they prevail against him? I cannot say, but I know this: my heart is stirred by their march!

'They seem so different from you or I, and from Horn or Nona, so far removed from the daily worries of Men or Elves. But still they march for us against the evil of Núrzum, against the evil of Saruman.

'Even now Leaflock and his herd have not retreated so far from Middle-earth as to abandon its people. It is worth remembering.

'It seems our friends have remembered something as well, [placeholder]. I told you it would happen, did I not? I am certain I did.'
